feed.title: SAP Community - Machine Learning
feed.subtitle: Machine Learning Q&A in SAP Community

entry.title: How can I parallelize the training of a HANA_ML MLPRegressor?
entry.content:
According to the documentation setting thread_ratio=1 means all available threads on SAP HANA will be used for training, but I can only see 5 threads of the scriptserver being active. This is exactly the same behavior as when training with the default value of thread_ratio=0. How can I speed up the training via parallelization?

from hana_ml.algorithms.pal.neural_network import MLPRegressor

mlp = MLPRegressor(hidden_layer_size=(layer1,layer2),
activation='relu',
output_activation='relu',
max_iter=iterations,
weight_init='normal',
training_style='batch',
normalization='z-transform',
thread_ratio=1)

mlp.fit(train_df, features=x_columns, label='y')

entry.title: Questions about SAP Joule
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are planning to enable SAP Joule. But before we proceed, we wanted to understand the capabilities of Joule with respect to SAP Sales Cloud Version 2. I had a few questions regarding it, please read through them and provide your insights.

I understand that SAP Joule currently has 3 Interaction Patterns: Transactional, Navigational and Informational. But I would like to know more about the following:

1. What are the Business Objects supported in Joule with respect to SAP Sales Cloud Version 2?
2. What are the use-cases that are supported in Joule with respect to SAP Sales Cloud Version 2?
3. What are the current limitations of Joule?
4. Is there a way to customize navigation capabilities of Joule from SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 to SAP ECC?

If there are any online sources that I could reference for the questions above, please provide those to me as well.

Thanks in advance,
Karthik C M.

entry.title: Detecting Handwritten vs. Digital Docs in SAP CAP + DOX
entry.content: I'm working on a solution using SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming) with Node.js, integrated with SAP Document Information Extraction (DOX). This project sends documents via API to the DOX service to extract relevant information from files such as invoices and receipts. My requirement here is to check whether the document is handwritten or computer-generated. This distinction could significantly enhance data accuracy and processing logic. If anyone has insights on integrating handwriting detection with SAP DOX or using pre-processing techniques for document classification, I’d love to connect and learn more.

entry.title: The AI Adoption Journey: Machine Learning- A Deeper Dive!
entry.content:
Hello all!

Last blog, we skimmed over some of the Machine Learning features that SAP Fieldglass has but I’ve since gotten to experiment with it more and I must talk about it!
First things first. Machine Learning is a part of the base AI for Fieldglass, which means its available for anyone that has Fieldglass. It blows my mind that it’s not used more!

So, why would anyone want to use these features? Like the example I gave in the last blog, getting a large influx of resumes from various job postings can be a substantial burden on your administrative team.

How does Resume Assessment work to resolve this? AI assists in identifying the right job seekers by screening submitted candidates in how close of a match they are to the job description.
I remember when I was starting college, the advice was to put all the important information around the middle of the page, where a person’s thumb would be holding it. This was the idea they used to have about “efficiency” when it came to reviewing resumes. I'm sure we've all heard little tips and tricks like that- repurposing keywords in the resumes, placing them somewhere specific on the page, even hacks on fonts to keep the readers eyes on the page! 
Now, we have AI that will comb through the candidate resumes to do a match on both skills and work experience.
Your business has more sway in this process than you might think! Buyers can prioritize the factors differently, depending on industry, job title or level of experience! A new field called Resume Assessment Weighting on the Contingent Type can be leveraged to indicate the level of importance the business deems appropriate.
This field contains four main categories that the buyer can set based on their preference to produce a banded score: Skills, Industry Experience, Work Experience and Qualifications.

The algorithm matches the skills on the resume The algorithm matches the skills listed on the resume against the application's skills library, analyzes the industry experience, work experience, and qualifications based on the preferences set using the Resume Assessment Weighting field, and produces that banded score. This scoring system uses a five-tier band: best, better, good, weak, no match) to indicate compatibility with the job posting description.
So why the banded score? This high-level score can let the administrative team know, immediately, who the most compatible candidates are for the Job Postings.  With this feature in use, businesses saw that 61% of candidates hired were ranked “Best” by resume assessment.
ML doesn’t stop here with the requisition process. There’s also an experience assessment and skills extraction The Experience Assessment will offer a percentile score (1-100%) based on skills and related experience, as well as skills extraction, where AI combs through the submitted resume, and will visually highlight skills and qualifications making them easier to see (freeing up your thumbs and saving paper). This not only speeds up the reviewing, short listing and hiring process. Customers that enabled this feature saw an over all 15% reduction in workers closed with a “do not hire” reason.

These seemingly simple change in automation removes bottlenecks in the process in speeding up review to hire but also cleans up the integrity of the workforce hired overall.

Of course, there is all this information and so much more to play with in an interactive setting on the SAP Fieldglass Product Work Zone. They have an amazing AI Hub that I strongly encourage you to explore: SAP Fieldglass Product Success Work Zone - AI Hub

Also, please check out this great series by Fabian Caelers on Quick Win Features to learn some more valuable tips and tricks to make the most of your solution: SAP Fieldglass - Quick Win Features - Episode 2 - SAP Community

Join me next week, as I get into the obscure gem that is O*NET code recommendations in Fieldglass and why that matters!

entry.content:

However, intelligent applications or insight apps require both source and target systems to be connected in order to enable the content. entry.title: Feature Engineering in SAP BTP: SAP HANA Cloud In-built ML vs. SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hello Team,

We are implementing a new predictive use case on SAP BTP. We've established our data ingestion strategy, where raw data from various enterprise sources (both SAP and non-SAP) is successfully ingested into SAP HANA Cloud via SAP Integration Suite.

Now, our primary focus is on the feature engineering phase for this data, which resides entirely within SAP HANA Cloud. We need to perform various transformations, including:

Calculating derived metrics (e.g., DaysSinceLastActivity, InteractionCount).

Aggregating historical data.

Leveraging capabilities for automated feature engineering.

Preparing the engineered features in a structured, consumable format for machine learning model training and inference.

Ensuring scalability, performance, governance, and reusability of these features.

We are specifically evaluating the best approach for this feature engineering. We see two primary paths within the SAP BTP landscape for data already in HANA Cloud:

Leveraging SAP HANA Cloud's In-built Machine Learning Capabilities: Utilizing its SQL/SQLScript, Predictive Analysis Library (PAL), Automated Predictive Library (APL), AutoML features, and Python Machine Learning Client directly within HANA Cloud.

Utilizing SAP Datasphere: Building and managing the feature engineering pipelines and feature store within Datasphere, which leverages HANA Cloud as its underlying engine.

Based on your experience with similar predictive projects on SAP BTP, we'd greatly appreciate your insights on the following:

For feature engineering on data already residing in SAP HANA Cloud, what are the key advantages and disadvantages of:

Relying primarily on SAP HANA Cloud's native ML and data manipulation capabilities?

Integrating SAP Datasphere into the architecture for feature engineering?

In which scenarios would you strongly recommend one approach over the other for a project like ours?

Are there specific types of feature engineering tasks (e.g., complex aggregations, specific derived metrics, automated feature generation) where one service truly excels when the data source is HANA Cloud?

Any architectural patterns, best practices, or practical experiences (including considerations for MLOps, governance, and long-term maintainability) would be highly valuable.

Thank you in advance for your contributions!

#SAPHANACloud, #SAPDatasphere, #MachineLearning, #FeatureEngineering

entry.title: Personalized Recommendations LMS: Need more clarity
entry.content:
I want to know more about this feature.

Personalized Recommendations on the New Learning Home Page | SAP Help Portal

In this it says "It includes their profile information, growth portfolio attributes, and their system interactions and activities."

What it means by Profile information and System Interactions? Will it cover all the modules to suggest courses?

and can you explain the interactions? what acts as an interaction in the system? also what information it takes from the Profile?

Do we have a detailed explanation for this feature?

Also, if my interest is Ex. Leadership, will it show all the courses related to Leadership? or just some courses.?

 

Also,  Can we know why a particular course was recommended? is it because I searched for it, or completed a course or any other thing? Can a user know that?

SAP SuccessFactors Learning Machine Learning SAP Learning Solution
